Expectation1: Communicate with clients and vendors regarding financial matters.
Situation1: A vendor sent a standard automated confirmation of a recent payment, to which a formal reply should be sent.
Expectation2: Arrive at the polling station during designated voting hours
Situation2: Late-afternoon errands leave just a couple of hours before the polls close.
Story: I glanced at the clock on my monitor: 4:30 p.m. The polling station would close at six, and I still had to pick up groceries on my way. My inbox pinged—a vendor had sent a payment confirmation, the kind that always required a formal reply. As the accountant, I knew the expectation: respond promptly, keep communication professional, maintain our reputation. But as a voter, I felt the weight of civic duty pressing on me. I’d promised myself I wouldn’t skip voting, not this year, not with so much at stake. My manager expected timely replies, and the vendor would notice any delay. Yet, if I left now, I could just make it to the polling station before it closed. My fingers hovered over the keyboard, torn between drafting the reply and grabbing my bag to rush out. The pressure built in my chest—responsibility to my job on one side, responsibility to my community on the other. I stared at the screen, heart pounding, caught between two worlds that both demanded my presence, knowing I couldn’t be in both places at once.
